document.title: The Persuasiveness of Pleasure: Play, Reciprocity, and Persuasion in Online Discussions

author.institution: University of Texas at San Antonio

document.abstract: This essay explores the role of pleasure in facilitating diverse modes of rhetorical participation in online discussion.
document.publication-title: The Journal of the Assembly for Expanded Perspectives on Learning

field.name: acknowledgements
field.value: Sue Hum is Associate Professor of English, specializing in rhetoric and composition, at the University of Texas at San Antonio, where she teaches graduate and undergraduate courses in writing. Her most recent works include Relations, Locations, Positions: Composition Theory for Writing Teachers (co-edited with Peter Vandenberg and Jennifer Clary-Lemon, NCTE, 2006) and Ways of Seeing, Ways of Speaking: The Integration of Rhetoric and Vision in Constructing the Real (co-edited with Kristie S. Fleckenstein and Linda T. Calendrillo, Parlor, 2007).
